items.title: Unraveling the regulative development and molecular mechanisms of identical sea urchin twins
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63111-z Experiments from over a century ago showed that dividing sea urchin embryos at the 2-cell stage yields two embryos, but the mechanisms of this phenomenon have not been shown. Here, they show that these embryos self-organize in an unusual way to pattern the body axes.

items.title: Hemispheric asymmetry of tau pathology is related to asymmetric amyloid deposition in Alzheimer’s Disease
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63564-2 Asymmetrical distribution of tau pathology in Alzheimer’s disease is linked to asymmetrical amyloid-beta deposition, not reduced brain connectivity, suggesting regional vulnerability plays a key role in determining the distribution of tau pathology.

items.title: Friedel oscillations and chiral superconductivity in monolayer NbSe<sub>2</sub>
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63319-z The nature of the dominant pairing mechanism in some two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides is still debated. Here, the authors predict that the Kohn-Luttinger mechanism induces chiral p-wave superconductivity in monolayer NbSe2.

items.title: Transient domain boundary drives ultrafast magnetisation reversal
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63571-3 The authors reveal that even within a few-nanometre thin films, ultrafast all-optical magnetisation switching is spatially inhomogeneous along the depth and driven by the picosecond propagation of a transient domain boundary.

items.title: Many plants naturalized as aliens abroad have also become more common within their native regions
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63293-6 How changes in species’ native occupancy over time relate to global naturalization success remains unclear. Here, the authors show that species with both high occupancy decades ago and increasing native occupancy ever since are more likely to become naturalized elsewhere.

items.title: Regio- and chemoselective catalytic partial transfer hydrogenation of quinolines by dinuclear aluminum species
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63460-9 While catalytic reduction of quinolines has gained interest as a way to provide direct and efficient access to tetrahydroquinolines or 1,2-dihydroquinolines, the catalytic synthesis of 1,2-dihydroquinolines remains underdeveloped. Here, the authors demonstrate a catalytic 1,2-reduction of quinolines using a dinuclear aluminum complex.

items.title: Accelerating development of polycyclic heteroaromatic emitters with small singlet–triplet energy gaps
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 05 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02352-1 A simple physical model based on electronic interactions between excited configurations enables the quick and reliable prediction of singlet–triplet energy gaps in polycyclic heteroaromatic emitters. Guided by this model, organic emitters with small singlet–triplet energy gaps can be designed for applications in organic light-emitting diodes with high efficiency and colour purity.

items.title: Local photocrosslinking of native tissue matrix regulates lung epithelial cell mechanosensing and function
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 05 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02329-0 Using visible-light-induced crosslinking, a local stiffening approach is developed for ex vivo mouse and human lung tissue as an early lung injury model, directing epithelial cell mechanosensing, differentiation and nascent protein deposition.

items.summary: Acharya et al. Approximately 90% of the stars in the Milky Way are on the main sequence, fusing hydrogen into helium through a network of nuclear reactions. This includes the nearest star, our Sun. A precise understanding of hydrogen burning is crucial to predicting its luminosity, neutrino production, and helioseismology. This review describes the theoretical and experimental work of the last decade that has advanced our understanding of the nuclear physics of hydrogen burning. It describes the plasma and atomic physics that influences the solar environment in which the nuclear reactions take place, as well as the diagnostics probes—including solar neutrinos and helioseismology—that allow us to test our resulting model of the solar interior. items.title: Will a child survive? Older siblings have a powerful influence
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 04 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02836-9 Swiss birth data from 1750 to 1870 reveal that girls who had lots of older brothers close to their own age were less likely to survive than were those who did not.

items.title: Inside a mosquito factory
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 04 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02806-1 Brazilian site could produce one kilo of mosquito eggs per week.

items.title: Changing tides ushered in the world’s first civilization
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 04 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02837-8 Construction of tidal irrigation systems helped to drive the formation of city states some 5,000 years ago.

items.title: Air pollution directly linked to increased dementia risk
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 04 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02844-9 Long-term exposure accelerates the development of Lewy body dementia and Parkinson’s disease with dementia in people who are predisposed to the conditions.

items.title: RFK Jr slings accusations and defends public-health upheaval at fiery hearing
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 04 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02845-8 Senators from both parties expressed scepticism about the US health secretary’s statements on COVID-19 vaccines and more.

items.title: Chemists cram record nine metals into trendy 2D material
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 04 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02839-6 MXenes, distant cousins of graphene, reach new heights of complexity — opening the way for use in advanced batteries and more.

items.title: Newfound immune cell in mice hints at why inflammation spikes with old age
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 04 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02788-0 Pathogen-consuming cells found in fat tissue also play a part in lipid balance.

items.title: Europe’s largest paper mill? 1,500 research articles linked to Ukrainian network
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 04 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02809-y A group of companies has flooded 380 journals with hundreds of suspect papers since 2017.

items.title: The origin of the axial Higgs is a hidden ferroaxial electronic density wave
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 04 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03029-x Experiments that probe the spontaneously broken symmetries in rare-earth tritellurides have revealed a previously hidden ferroaxial density wave arising from intertwined charge and orbital order, which is observed to produce the axial Higgs mode.

items.title: Tau accelerates tubulin exchange in the microtubule lattice
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 04 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03003-7 Beyond its known role in stabilizing microtubules, it is now shown that tau protein actively promotes lattice defect repair by enhancing tubulin turnover at topological defects.

items.title: Space-time crystals from particle-like topological solitons
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 04 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02344-1 A continuous mesoscale space-time crystal phase is reported from a nematic liquid crystal driven by light.
